scenarios.baseline: Finland keeps the eastern land border closed for an extended period, while allowing only tightly controlled exceptions like limited rail logistics via Vainikkala and selected cargo/maritime traffic. Border governance hardens through the Border Security Act and incremental legal extensions, and technology is increasingly used for monitoring and enforcement. Border-region economies remain pressured as trade and tourism stay suppressed, and adaptation shifts toward domestic markets and state support.
scenarios.plausible: Finland moves from a “closed border” posture to a “controlled corridor” model: a small number of crossings reopen for pre-approved freight and essential travel under strict screening. Technology-enabled checks (data sharing, risk scoring, surveillance, and automated monitoring) become standard practice, backed by updated legislation. Trade partially recovers through limited channels, but tourism remains low and border governance stays security-first.
scenarios.wildcard: A sudden hybrid pressure campaign—such as an abrupt surge in irregular migration or coordinated disruptions—forces Finland to escalate emergency border measures and rapidly expand surveillance and patrol capacity. Rail and maritime exceptions are suspended or heavily restricted, and cross-border movement becomes unpredictable. The economic shock deepens in border regions, while international support and crisis coordination intensify.
scenarios.preposterous: A dramatic political breakthrough leads to a rapid normalization where the border reopens widely, trade and tourism rebound fast, and Finland and Russia establish an unusually cooperative cross-border governance regime. At the same time, Finland relies on near-total “smart border” automation—drones, sensors, and AI triage—to keep friction low while maintaining security. The border becomes a showcase of openness-plus-high-tech control rather than a long-term closure zone.

scenarios.baseline: Finland continues building the 200 km high-tech fence in phases, while steadily strengthening the Border Guard’s legal powers, staffing, and criminal-intelligence capabilities. Surveillance technology and infrastructure become the default way to manage risk on the eastern border, with enforcement more standardized and resilient. The result is a “harder” border that is harder to breach but more expensive to maintain.
scenarios.plausible: The fence is completed and integrated into a broader layered system: sensors, patrol routines, data-driven screening, and stronger investigative tools against cross-border crime. Legislative updates clarify preparedness powers and enable faster response, while human resources are expanded to reduce fatigue and improve readiness. Smuggling and hostile probing shift tactics rather than disappear, pushing Finland toward continuous adaptation and periodic upgrades.
scenarios.wildcard: A sudden security shock—such as a coordinated border surge, sabotage against construction sites, or a major cross-border crime network breakthrough—forces rapid acceleration of infrastructure and emergency legal measures. Temporary “maximum control” procedures are introduced (expanded restricted areas, fast-track procurements, intensified intelligence operations), and the fence becomes a crisis-response centerpiece rather than a gradual project. Operational strain rises sharply, and public debate focuses on tradeoffs between speed, cost, and civil liberties.
scenarios.preposterous: Finland deploys a near-fully autonomous “smart border” where AI-assisted detection, drones, and automated barriers handle most routine enforcement, and human patrols intervene only when the system flags high-risk events. At the same time, the border becomes a showcase export project—Finland sells the model abroad and turns the eastern border into a testing ground for next-generation security tech. The fence shifts from a defensive necessity to a global demonstrator platform.

scenarios.baseline: Finland sustains a heightened Defence Forces posture near the eastern border through regular readiness exercises, expanded local-defence training, and steady modernization such as the F-35 program and Patria’s assembly work. Reservist policy changes (including a higher age limit) increase available manpower, while capabilities like stockpiled landmines and improved command-and-control strengthen deterrence. The overall effect is a more credible, routine “high readiness” stance without major force surges.
scenarios.plausible: Border-adjacent readiness becomes more integrated and scalable: exercises increasingly link local defence, rapid reinforcement, and NATO coordination, supported by the emerging NATO Northern Command structure. As F-35 deliveries and domestic support capacity mature, Finland improves airpower readiness and sustainment, enabling faster response options and stronger joint operations. The posture remains defensive but more visibly networked, with reservists used more frequently in structured rotations.
scenarios.wildcard: A sudden regional crisis or major provocation triggers an accelerated readiness spike: larger call-ups, more frequent snap exercises, temporary deployment shifts toward the east, and intensified air policing and reconnaissance. Landmine planning and barrier preparations move from “stockpile and policy” into rapid operational readiness, while NATO coordination becomes near-continuous. The posture shifts from routine deterrence to sustained crisis footing, creating strain on personnel and logistics.
scenarios.preposterous: Finland establishes a permanently forward-leaning “border shield” with near-constant high-readiness rotations, persistent drone and sensor coverage, and continuous NATO-led joint training in the region. F-35s and air-defence assets are kept on an always-on alert cycle, and reservists are mobilized in a highly active, semi-regular service model. The eastern border becomes one of Europe’s most militarized deterrence zones even without an active conflict.

scenarios.baseline: Finland deepens international defence cooperation through NATO integration, recurring large exercises (e.g., Nordic Response/Steadfast Defender), and the full implementation of the Defence Cooperation Agreement (DCA) that enables infrastructure and host-nation support. Interoperability improves year by year as procedures, logistics, and planning become more standardized with key partners. The overall effect is stronger deterrence through routine multinational presence and readiness, without permanent basing being the main driver.
scenarios.plausible: Cooperation becomes more operationally “plug-and-play”: Finland and allies develop standing exercise cycles, pre-planned reinforcement routes, and upgraded infrastructure under the DCA to shorten response times. Joint training expands in the High North and across Finland, and planning increasingly focuses on cross-domain operations (air, land, maritime, cyber, and logistics). Finland remains the framework nation for its own defence, but allied support becomes faster, more predictable, and more visible.
scenarios.wildcard: A regional escalation or major incident forces a rapid shift from exercises to sustained operational reassurance: allied units rotate through Finland more frequently, infrastructure upgrades are accelerated, and DCA arrangements are used at high tempo. Political pressure rises—domestically and internationally—over the scale of presence, rules for host-nation support, and the risk of spillover. Cooperation intensifies quickly, but so do adversary countermeasures and hybrid activity.
scenarios.preposterous: Finland becomes the primary Northern European hub for allied operations, with near-continuous multinational forces training and operating from Finnish bases under an expanded DCA framework. Exercises blur into persistent deployments, and Finland hosts a de facto “always-on” NATO presence that reshapes regional military geography. The country shifts from being a highly capable national defender to a central staging and command platform for the entire High North.

trends.description: Yle reported that Finland’s Defence Minister Antti Häkkänen said on 18 June 2025 that there was "nothing surprising or dramatic" in Russia’s base buildup near the Finnish border.

scenarios.baseline: Russia continues gradual force reorganization and infrastructure upgrades relevant to Finland’s border, while periodic air and maritime activity creates recurring alerts and occasional suspected airspace violations. Open-source reporting and satellite imagery keep highlighting incremental changes rather than a single decisive buildup. Finland responds with steady monitoring and readiness, treating the activity as long-term pressure and signalling rather than an imminent invasion indicator.
scenarios.plausible: Russia increases the tempo and clarity of its posture near the Finnish border by forming or reactivating units, improving bases and logistics, and conducting more frequent exercises and patrol patterns. Air activity becomes more assertive (though still mostly below the threshold of direct escalation), and “grey-zone” signalling—close approaches, jamming, ambiguous probing—becomes more regular. Finland and NATO adjust by tightening air policing, intelligence collection, and reinforcement planning, producing a more visibly contested security environment.
scenarios.wildcard: A sudden spike in Russian activity—such as an unexpected large-scale snap exercise, rapid redeployment from another theatre, or a serious border/air incident—creates a short-warning crisis. Miscalculation risk rises as both sides surge readiness, increase air operations, and compress decision timelines. Even if it de-escalates, the episode locks in higher long-term alert levels and accelerates Finnish/NATO posture changes.
scenarios.preposterous: Russia announces a dramatic “new northern front” posture and rapidly mass-builds major formations and permanent infrastructure opposite Finland, coupled with near-daily high-risk air activity. Finland responds by transforming the border region into a permanent high-readiness zone with constant allied presence and continuous air operations. The region becomes one of Europe’s most militarized flashpoints despite no formal outbreak of war.
